documents.title: lunchtime summary
text: philip hammond , the foreign secretary , has said that that the british security services are studying the gun attack on the canadian parliament to see what the implications are for westminster .

giving evidence to the intelligence and security committee he said : our agencies are in close contact with their canadian counterparts and , as you would expect , are already analysing what happened in canada and the implications for us .
he said that the intelligence agencies were the exact opposite '' of their movie counterparts when it came to respecting privacy .
there were robust '' legal safeguards to limit what surveillance they could carry out , and multiple layers of oversight , he said .
but there was also a culture of caution .
there 's also a very important safeguard provided by the culture within the agencies , which is the exact opposite of what some movies might like to suggest .
the agencies are extremely cautious , extremely focused on their responsibility to maintain the culture of proportionality and necessity in everything they do .
and there is an atmosphere in the agencies which is very far from a gung-ho approach .
it is very cautious , very measured .
he said ministers who sign surveillance warrants all now believe that one day they will have to justify their actions before an iraq-style inquiry .
this meant there was a very strong political incentive '' to authorise surveillance only where it was justified , he said .

perhaps it is a feature of the times that we live in , but i 'm sure i can speak for all of my colleague who sign warrants that we all have , in the back of our minds , that at some point in the future we will - not might be , but will - be appearing before some inquiry or tribunal or court accounting for the decisions that we 've made and essentially accounting for the way we 've applied the proportionality and necessity tests .
there is a very strong political incentive in the system to apply these tests narrowly and in a way that minimises the scope of the agencies to interpret warrants that are issuesd .
he said this was why he thought it was better for politicians to sign intercept warrants , not judges .
judges would only be concerned about the legality of a warrant , whereas politicians had to taken into account the political need for proportionality too , he said .
he said he did not accept the claim that bulk data collection amounted to mass surveillance .
intrusion only took place when a particular item of data was actually investigated , he said .
he said there were strict legal safeguards that determined when this was allowed to happen .
but he also that a country like britain simply did not have the resources to examine all the data it collected in that kind of intrusive manner .
jeremy hunt , the health secretary , and andy burnham , his labour opposite number , have both claimed that a report on the future of the nhs vindicates their party 's stance on health policy .
see 12.29pm .

simon stevens , the nhs england chief executive , has defended the privatisation of services as a way of helping patients get treatment but insisted that the health service would continue to do most of the work .

ed miliband has promised he will introduce an immigration reform bill within a month of winning the next election that offers clear , credible and concrete '' measures to deal with the concerns of voters .

mps , including former coalition ministers who have since returned to the backbenches , have declared more than £ 7.1m earnings from second jobs and outside interests , according to parliamentary records .

as james ball and harry davies report , an analysis by the guardian shows that 26 mps declared more earnings from directorships , paid employment or shareholdings than they did from their parliamentary salary , with more than 20 declaring more than £ 100,000 in outside earnings in the latest register of members ' interests .
one of the top earners is charles hendry , who was until september 2012 a minister of state at the department of energy and climate change .
nick clegg has backed fiona woolf as the chair of the government 's inquiry into child sex abuse , saying she was a credible person '' for the role .
the work and pension selection committee has announced n inquiry into how the benefit sanctions regime is administered .
that 's all from me for today .
thanks for the comments .
philip hammond giving evidence to the intelligence and security committee tv
julian lewis goes next .
he reads out some intelligence legislation .
could n't this be made easier for the public to understand ?
hammond says most legislation could be made easier for the public to understand .
hammond says he and his colleagues who sign warrants all think that at some point in the future they might have to appear before a tribunal to justify what they did .
there is a strong political incentive to act in a way that is proportionate , he says .
and that 's it .
i 'll post a summary soon .
lord butler goes next .
q : are you in favour of increasing the transparency of the activities of the intelligence agencies ?
hammond says he thinks the public would be reassured if they knew more about how hte intelligence agencies operate .
but there would be disadvantages .
the snowden revelations showed that revealing information about how the agencies work can cause problems .
as a result of the revelations , al-qaida changed the way they operate , and criminals started using different communication routes , he says .
hammond says the british intelligence agencies are analysing the attack on the canadian parliament , and what its implications are for the uk .
he says he spends several hours a week '' dealing with warrant applications .
q : would it be better if judges signed warrants , not secretaries of state ?
hammond says this would result in the checks being looser .
a judge would only look at whether something was legal .
secretaries of state only approve things if they are legal .
but they also apply a political test ; can this be politically justified .
he says the most difficult warrants never involve legal difficulties .
what makes the decisions difficult are the political considerations involved , he says .
he says that when he travels abroad , people are surprised how hands-on british ministers are when it comes to approving surveillance warrants .
labour 's fiona mactaggart goes next .
q : would it be possible to codify these arrangements in law ?
hammond says you could codify them in law .
but whether that would be helpful is another matter .
q : would public confidence be enhanced if there was greater public understanding of these matters ?
hammond says britain 's relationships with other , foreign agencies are relationships of trust .
although britain might want to be more open , foreign partners do not necessarily want this .
julian lewis goes next .
q : section 7 of the intelligences services act has been described as the james bond section ( ie , licence to kill ) .
it appears to authorise mi6 agents to do whatever they want if approved by a warrant .
hammond says that agents have to act within the terms of the warrant they are given , and that these are always tightly drawn up .
the act gives the secretary of state the power to render legal an act that would otherwise be illegal when carried out abroad .
but the secretary of state 's accountability ensures that these warrants are used properly .
the intelligence services commissioner also has the right to examine these warrants , he says .
sir menzies campbell , the former lib dem leader , goes next .
q : information can be obtained under the intelligence services act .
is this clear to the public ?
hammond says he authorises warrants under this act .
a section 7 warrant is only issued in relation to proceedings abroad .
he says the public would be surprised and reassured '' how much authorisation is required , even for relatively trivial operations .
q : would more transparency about what can be authorised help ?
hammond says the legislation is clear .
what is authorised in practice is well within '' the parameters of what could be authorised under the act .
hammond says the test he applies is that , if he were able to explain it to a panel of reasonable constituents , they would accept what he was doing was reasonable and proportionate .
lord butler goes next .
q : do you think there is a case for giving citizens more privacy , because more data is now shared on the internet ?
hammond says data has become more accessible .
that is driving the demand for more data .
q : you can learn more now about individuals from internet data than in the past .
is our definition of communications data sufficiently tight to prevent people looking at the content ?
yes , says hammond .
there are robust protections for content .
decisions to investigate content have to be approved by ministers .
q : if gchq examine external information , would they have to keep that to themselves ?
or could they share that with mi6 or mi5 ?
hammond says they can , where appropriate , pass that on to other agencies .
sir malcolm rifkind goes next .
q : there is a lot of public concern about this .
is there not a case for the government drawing up a document that explains the difference between an internal communication and an external one ?
hammond says people need to understand that their communication will only be examined under the authority of a warrant .
q : why not publish a document clarifying this ?
hammond says he will think about this .
perhaps the committee might like to do this in its report .
rifkind says this is a matter for the government .
q : what happens if i upload photographs into the cloud , into dropbox ?
if i 'm the only person accessing it , is that an internal communication , or an external one ?
hammond says it would be an external communication if the server were abroad .
q : if i read the new york times website , is that an external communication ?
hammond says that would count as an external communication .
q : charles farr from the home office recently said facebook posts were external communications .
if i posted something on facebook , to be read only by my friends , all of whom were based in the uk , should n't that be an internal communication ?
hammond says that would be treated as an external communication .
but the agencies would need to modify their warrant , under 16 ( 3 ) , because one of the parties was in the uk .
( that 's a modification to a section 84 warrant . )
this is not about citizenship , he says .
it is a matter of where the person is based .
julian lewis goes next .
q : can you confirm that if the sender and recipient of an email are in the uk , it will always be treated as an internal communication , even if it is routed through a foreign server ?
hammond says these issues have become more complicated because of technology .
if an email originates in the uk , it is treated as an internal email , in terms of the law about accessing its content , he says .
data routed through a foreign server could be intercepted through a section 84 warrant .
but , if it were an internal email , its contents could not be read without a section 81 warrant , he says .
if both parties are outside the uk , the email could be read under a section 84 warrant , he says .
q : so an email is internal if just one person , sender or recipient , is in the uk ?
hammond says both sender and recipient have to be in the uk for an email to be internal .
lord butler goes next .
q : can you say how wide the categories are when information is searched .
for example , would it be all emails from syria ?
hammond says he would rather discuss this in the private session they are going to have later .
q : but can you say anything that would reassure the public ?
hammond says he does not want to give any information about the type of selectors that are used .
q : in the us the nsa has said it up 1.6 % of internet traffic .
but it says it only examines 0.00004 % of it .
can you give similar figures ?
hammond says he can say more in the private session .
sir malcolm rifkind goes next .
q : if the us can release these figures , why ca n't you ?
hammond says that is a matter for the us .
julian lewis goes next .
q : critics of the collection of bulk data would never suggest states look at all of the data all at once .
but their concern is about the state being able to search it .
how do you search the data ?
you could carry out a search for the wrong purpose .
hammond says that is true .
but in the uk very strict criteria are in place .
these are set out in warrants .
there are legal criteria , and the secretary of state signing a warrant exercises political judgment .
hammond says , when he signs a warrant , he does not just consider whether it is reasonable and proportionate .
he also considers whether this would be politically acceptable .
q : but what would stop a rogue employee conducting his own searches ?
hammond said he asked this question himself when he visited gchq .
controls are in place to stop agents misusing the system , he says .
q : that did not stop the americans losing information .
hammond says , if that is a reference to edward snowden , he stole information .
hammond says the automated application of selection criteria by a comuter , and the discarding of 99.9 % of the data does not amount to intrusion .
intrusion only arises as an issue at the point where the data is interrogated , he says .
mark field , a conservative , goes next .
q : how important is bulk interception ?
hammond says it is important .
he has been described as building the haystack which you then search .
most of the information is discarded after a very short period of time .
but it does allow for filtering .
only a tiny , tiny fraction '' of bulk data collected will ever be seen by a human analyst , he says .
q : how would you respond to the allegation that these capabilities are a matter of great concern ?
hammond says he does not accept the contention that bulk data collection amounts to mass surveillance .
in a country like ours , having the ability to do bulk data collection does not lead to mass surveillance .
the resources are not available for that , he says .
but in other countries , which devote more resources to intelligence , the situation might be different .
but there are also safeguards in terms of the rules in place .
mass surveillance would be illegal , he says .
there is rigorous oversight '' in place .
even if it were practical , which it is n't for resource reasons , mass surveillance would be illegal .
he says as a citizen his greatest reasssurance is the resource one .
even the most intrusive state in the world would not be able to mass-analyse individuals ' communications .
lord butler goes next .
q : is greater intrusion into privacy justified when the threat is greater ?
broadly speaking , that is right , hammond says .
he is not talking on a week by week basis .
but as the threat grows over time , people want to be kept safe .
q : do you ever authorise mi6 and gchq to undertake intrusion operations in the uk ?
hammond says , under the law , he has to authorise their operations , so he would sign warrants for anything in the uk .
q : would you always discuss these with the home secretary ?
not necessarily , says hammond .
julian lewis , a conservative , goes first .
q : have your views on these issues changed since you were given responsibility for mi6 and gchq as foreign secretary ?
hammond says when he was defence secretary he started to see intelligence material , and started to get a better idea of how the agencies work .
he developed a better sense of how judgments are made balancing privacy and security .
q : did it come as a surprise to you to learn how much they intrude into privacy ?
no , says hammond .
he says he was surprised to learn how strong the safeguards were .
and that is not just a legal requirement , he says .
there is a culture that is very cautious , very measured '' .
it is the complete opposite of what some movies suggest , he says .
sir malcolm rifkind , the committee chairman , opens by saying philip hammond has given evidence to the public before ( when he was defence secretary , presumably ) .
but this is the first time hammond has given evidence to it in public .
he invites hammond to make an opening statement .
hammond says the public 's views about the right balance between privacy and security will oscillate from time to time .
the government 's duty is to get the right balance , he says .

documents.title: philip hammond 's evidence to the intelligence and security committee
text: philip hammond , the foreign secretary , is about to give evidence to the intelligence and security committee .
it is carrying out an inquiry into privacy and security .
according to the committee , these are some of the issues it will explore .

· expectations of privacy , and the extent to which it may be appropriate to intrude into an individual 's privacy in order to protect the rights and safety of others ; · whether it is acceptable to use intrusive capabilities in a targeted way against known threats , and whether it is ever acceptable to use such capabilities to gather information in larger quantities ; · whether the current statutory framework governing and regulating the agencies ' intrusive activities delivers those principles ; and , · whether there is scope for greater transparency in this area .

documents.title: jeremy hunt v andy burnham - summary
text: jeremy hunt photographer : justin tallis/afp/getty images tallis/afp/getty images if the nhs is going to be one of the key issues at the election , these exchanges between jeremy hunt and andy burnham were a dry run .
they were informative , argumentative and spiky ; well worth watching , in other words , which is not something that you can normally say about a commons urgent question .
here are the main points .
hunt welcomed the nhs five year forward view report , saying it was essentially positive and optimistic '' and a blueprint for the direction of travel '' .
the government would publish a considered response in due course , he said .
he appealed for a more measured '' debate on health , saying labour and the conservatives should acknowledge more often that they agree to a large extent on health policy .

i think the public would say we 'd have a more measured , intelligent sensible debate , the kind of debate they want to hear , if we started talking about the things we agree on a bit more , instead of constantly pretending there are vast disagreements .

as examples of issues on which the two parties agreed , hunt cited the need for more integration of health and social care , which he said was happening , the need for more investment in primary care and more gps , and the need for more care to be delivered closer to home .
( as norman smith pointed out earlier - see 10.55am - hunt seemed to have forgotten yesterday 's pmqs . )
hunt accused burnham of shallow party-politicking '' .
he appealed for a more measured debate in his opening statement but , after hearing burnham 's response , he hit back .
this [ report ] does not endorse labour 's narrative .
it exposes it for the shallow party-politicking that we 've had from [ burnham ] .
hunt said the report disproved labour claims that the nhs was on the point of collapse .
i would like to congratulate [ burnham ] on his houdini-like spin in the way he is approaching this report .
he has been constantly telling this house that the nhs is on the point of collapse .
but the chief executive of nhs england says that the nhs has been remarkable successful in weathering the pressures of recent years .
burnham said the nhs report endorsed labour 's health policy , not the conservatives ' .
he claimed that this was one reason why hunt did not offer to make a commons statement about it , and instead only came to the commons when labour tabled an urgent questions .
we know why he wants to distance himself from this report ; it endorses key planks of labour 's plan , and leaves him with big questions to answer labour has set out its plan .
today the nhs endorses that plan .

as examples of proposals in the report that correspond to labour policy , burnham cited the call for gps to get better resources , the call for faster cancer diagnosis , the call for hospitals to become better integrated with other parts of the health system and the call for more radical action to tackle obesity .
burnham challenged hunt to accept that the government 's voluntary responsibility deal with the food industry was not working .
hunt and burnham both used the report to defend their stance on competition in the nhs .
burnham said there was not one mention of competition in the report .
he went on : that 's because it creates fragmentation , when the future demands integration .
but hunt said the fact that competition was not mentioned showed that current competition policy was not a problem .
he told burnham : [ burnham ] has told this house constantly that the biggest threat to the nhs is privatisation and competition .
and here we are , in this report , not one single mention of competition and privatisation as a threat .
and yet this is a report that he says endorses labour 's plans .
hunt said the report showed that labour was wrong to call for repeal of the health act .
the report said there should be no more structural change in the nhs , he said .
but repealing the act would amount to structural change .
it would strip clinical commissioning groups ( ccgs ) of their powers .
burnham said hunt 's decision not to come to the commons voluntarily to make a statement about the report showed the lose of public accountability generated by the government 's health reforms .
he told hunt : i do n't know who runs the nhs these days , but i do know it 's certainly not him .
andy burnham rousseau/pa
the urgent question is now over .
i 'll post a summary shortly .
philip hollobone , a conservative , says thousands of gps will retire in the next few years .
what can be done about this ?
hunt says this is an important issue .
the government is looking at how it can make it easier for gps to return to work .
and it is trying to take measures to reduce the burn out '' that gps experience .
labour 's sheila gilmore asks hunt if he is worried that reduced tax revenues have led to higher borrowing .
hunt says that that is why the government has had to cut spending .
it has taken tough decisions that were opposed by labour .
labour 's lilian greenwood asks why hunt is not doing more to tackle the health problems caused by cheap alcohol .
hunt says the government approach to alcohol is not the same as its one towards tobacco .
there is nothing wrong with drinking alcohol in moderate quantities , he says .
bob blackman , a conservative , says we should aspire to a smoke-free britain .
smoking rates are going down .
he says he would like to see tobacco firms taxed out of existence '' .
but is n't it irresponsible to base funding plans on a tax on an industry that may not exist in the future ?
( that 's a reference to labour 's proposed levy on the tobacco industry . )
hunt says that is a good point .
tom blenkinsop , a labour mp , asks about nhs closures in his constituency .
does hunt take any responsibility ?
he always seems to blame someone else .
hunt disagrees .
he takes full responsibility for the nhs , he says .
given the pressures it is facing , the nhs is doing well .
sir tony baldry , a conservative , says a recent commonwealth fund report found the nhs top amongst international health systems .
so is n't it unedifying for labour to go on about the nhs failing .
hunt said the report had one startling fact in it .
when labour left office , the nhs came seventh for patient-centred care .
now it comes top , he says .
andrew george , a lib dem , asks how clinical commissioning groups can integrate services if they are forced to outsource services .
hunt says they are not forced to outsource services .
hunt says the report has lots of examples of how the new structures are integrating care .
that is why it would be wrong to do what labour wants , and scrap the health act and the new powers it gives to clinical commissioning groups .
hunt says this government has put 18 hospitals into special measures - more than 10 % .
the government has been criticised for this .
but the hospitals have improved , and six have come out of special measures .
the new inspection regime has been a success , he says .
labour 's heidi alexander asks what proportion of nhs land being sold will be used to create care provision for older people .
hunt says he would like to see more nhs land sold of for this purpose .
the report says it is important to take a more holistic approach to care , covering such issues as housing for older people , he says .
the bbc 's norman smith makes a good point on twitter .
norman smith ( @ bbcnormans ) jeremy hunt calls for `` more measured debate '' over # nhs .
er yesterday '' s # pmqs ? ?
labour 's nick brown asks if hunt thinks english nhs trusts can clear their deficits just by efficiency savings .
hunt says this will be challenging .
oliver colville , a conservative , asks what further role pharmacies could play .
hunt says it would help if they had better access to nhs records .
labour 's dennis skinner says the nhs has been a political football ever since 1947 .
the tories fought against it then , and have fought against it ever since .
the report does not back the government 's health reorganisation , he says .
labour increased nhs funding by three times in real terms .
if that had continued , people would not be dying of cancer because of lack of testing .
hunt and his posh people on millionaire 's row '' have opposed the very existence of the nhs .
that is why it will be the biggest issue at the election .
hunt says that kind of rhetoric does the whole country a disservice .
if the conservatives felt like that , they would not have protected the nhs budget .
the report , written by a former labour adviser ( simon stevens ) , says the nhs has been remarkably successful over the last five years , hunt says .
liz mcinnes , the new mp for heywood and middleton , says many people in her constituency can not see a gp within a week .
what will the report do about that ?
hunt says the government has introduced personal gps for every nhs pate
david tredinnick , a conservative , asks hunt if he will promote more integrated care .
hunt says he wants more person-centred care .
the report is a big stepping stone towards this , he says .
hunt is responding to burnham .
he says he spoke to soon when he talked about a more measured tone .
hunt says he has welcomed the report .
burnham keeps saying the nhs is on the point of collapse .
but the report does not endorse that , he says .
and burnham keeps complaining about nhs privatisation .
but the report does not even mention this , he says .
hunt says burnham said it was irresponsible to increase nhs funding .
( he is referring to a pre-2010 quote . )
but the government has increased nhs funding .
he says the report does not endorse labour 's stance .
it exposes it as shallow party politicking '' .
andy burnham , the shadow health secretary , is responding .
he says the report covers nhs spending worth £ 550bn .
yet hunt was not proposing to make a statement to mps .
he says he does not know who runs the nhs .
but it is not hunt .
hunt is running away from the report because it endorses labour policies , he says .
he challenges hunt to accept the need for more gps .
and he asks why the government will not match labour 's pledge to give patients cancer tests within a week .
the report does not mention competition , he says .
the report welcomes labour 's plans .
where are hunt 's plans ?

documents.title: urgent question on the nhs five year forward view report
text: andy burnham , the shadow health secretary , asks for a statement on the report .
jeremy hunt , the health secretary , is replying .
he says the report sets out challenges facing the nhs , but that it is essentially positive and optimistic '' .
he says it recognises a strong nhs needs a strong economy .
it proposes new models of care , he says .
it talks about continued opportunities for efficiency savings .
these could be increased above the long-term efficiency savings rate , he says .
and it proposes better integrating public health into the broader nhs agenda , especially in relation to obesity and smoking .
the government will be responding to the report in detail in due course , he says .
but it is an important contribution to the debate .
all sides of the house have welcomed it , he says .
so he hopes this can be the start of a more measured '' debate on the nhs .
simon stevens was interviewed on the today programme this morning .
today invited listeners to submit questions , and much of the interview was about the use of private providers in the nhs .
jeremy hunt has used his twitter feed to criticise this line of questioning .
jeremy hunt ( @ jeremy hunt ) real shame 2 see key today prog interview wth simon stevens on # 5yfv hijacked by 38 degrees public/private scaremongering .

documents.title: andy burnham on the nhs five year forward view report
text: andy burnham , the shadow health secretary , has also been giving interviews on the nhs five year forward view report .
here are some of the main points he has been making .
burnham welcomed the simon stevens report .

it 's a good report , and it 's a fair challenge to all of the political parties , its calling for more money , it 's calling for big changes to the way services are delivered , and for radical action on public health , and speaking for labour , i can say today that i am ready to accept those challenges and pledge the action that is needed in all three areas .
we have committed to more money for the nhs in the next parliament .
he challenged the conservatives to say they would match labour 's commitment to increase nhs spending .
labour is committed to putting an extra £ 2.5bn into the nhs every year .
he claimed the extra money proposed by labour would begin to flow straight away '' into the nhs .

documents.title: jeremy hunt on the nhs five year forward view report
text: jeremy hunt , the health secretary , will be responding to an urgent question on the nhs five year forward view report in about 20 minutes .
he has already been talking about it in tv interviews .
here are some of the points he 's been making .
hunt said the proposals in the report were achievable .

i think it is a positive report because there 's a lot of doom and gloom about the nhs but if you look at his report , it actually says that this is doable and that we can have the kind of nhs that we want , which looks after an ageing population with dignity and respect .
he suggested that increasing nhs spending by £ 8bn , as the report recommends , was feasible .
what they 're saying is you need to increase spending in real terms on the back of a strong economy .
we 've actually increased spending in this parliament by £ 5bn but you 're right , there is massive pressure on the frontline .
he said the government supported plans to change the way care was delivered .
what this report says , and it 's very much in line with government strategy , is that we need to change the model of care so that we 're not just depending on hospitals .
we need to be much better at looking after people in the community , in their homes , using gp practices , catching people before they get seriously ill .
he said individuals would have to take more responsibility for their own health .
people have to start taking responsibility for their own healthcare ; bosses have to take responsibility for their own employees .
if we have a joint endeavour on this , we can start helping people to be healthier , fitter , particularly children in schools .
i 've taken the quotes from politicshome .

documents.title: nick clegg 's lbc phone-in - summary
text: here are the main points from nick clegg 's phone-in .
clegg defended the home office 's decision to appoint fiona woolf as head of the child abuse inquiry .
he said he was comfortable with the appointment , that the home office had done due diligence '' before appointing her and that he had not seen anything to suggest they made a mistake .
i think fiona woolf is obviously a very credible person the home office did their due diligence and they clearly do n't feel that the reasons given somehow disqualify fiona woolf from the job .
and i have n't heard anything yet which suggests to me that the home secretary has made the wrong decision .
he defended the decision to release harry roberts , the prisoner who killed three police officers 45 years ago .

clegg would not say what he personally felt about this , but he said that it was right that these decisions were left to the parole board and he resisted an invitation to say that theresa may , the home secretary , should overturn the decision .

clegg says mike read does n't even like it any more .
it 's a white singer singing for a party that has just gone into alliance with polish holocaust deniers .
it is not a great look , he says .
ukip do not appeal to people who want this country to be an open , diverse place .
q : what can be done to improve dental care for kids ?
clegg says lots of children turn up to school with poor teeth .
he will look into this .
he asks the caller if having a healthy meal at lunchtime helps .
absolutely , says the caller .
q : your election strategist , ryan coetzee , was photographed with a paper showing your election priorities .
is he not fit for purpose ?
clegg says there is no secret what the lib dem priorities are .
if he had announced this , the media would have taken no notice .
q : what about your plan to allow couples to share their parental leave ?
clegg says this has been attacked by the daily mail .
they are miserable .
they think this will cost money .
it wo n't .
they need to move with the times .
q : they probably have more readers than you have voters .
clegg says the idea that mums and dads should decide who takes the time off is a simple one .
he is introducing this idea into the civil service .
q : how many firms have you actually run ?
clegg says if you ask employers , they favour this .
q : how much time did you take off when your children were born .
not much for his third son , says clegg .
at that point he was lib dem leader .
but he took more time off when his first son was born , to enable his wife to go back to work early .
q : [ from a canadian ] what are you going to do about the way legal immigrants are being disadvantaged ?
people like me with indefinite leave to remain need to have a document to apply for jobs and housing .
but it takes four or five months to get this .
and we can not work until we get it .
i can not even apply for benefits , even though i have lived here for more than 30 years .
clegg says he does not know the details of this .
he will take the caller 's details , and get back to him .
q : a recent poll showed you coming bottom out of the main four party leaders on trust .
why ?
clegg says polls come and go .
as soon as the lib dems went into coalition , they lost some support .
q : you feel strongly about this .
you are not faking .
your wife recently said women often fake things ?
clegg says his wife miriam was encouraging girls to be more confident .
q : can you tell when she is faking ?
clegg says he is not getting drawn into that .
he supports what she was saying about self-confidence .
q : do you agree with theresa may that harry roberts , the police killer , should be freed .
clegg says this is decision for the probation board .
q : may could block it if she wanted .
yes , says clegg .
q : should she ?
clegg says he is not going to second guess what the professionals decided .
he wants to protect the system that allows professionals to take these decisions .
q : how do you feel about this ?
clegg says this is not about his feelings .
these decisions should not be taken on the basis of emotions .
q : what do you think about asylum seekers who commit serious offences ?
should they be deported ?
clegg says people can not come here , expect generosity , and then abuse that .
q : so you would favour people like this being deported ?
clegg says the rules have been changed .
it is harder now to appeal against deportation .
some 22,000 foreign national offenders have been deported since 2010 , he says .
q : what do you think of theresa may 's judgment in appointing fiona woolf to head the child abuse inquiry ?
should n't woolf have to resign ?
it smells of a cover-up .
clegg says he does not entirely agree .
he has not heard anything that suggests may made the wrong decision .
woolf is a very credible person .
q : so you are comfortable with the appointment ?
yes , says clegg .
the home office did their due diligence .
they clearly do n't feel that the relationship with lord brittan means she can not do the job .
q : but she attended dinner parties with him , and she and brittan were friends .
clegg says the inquiry is n't just about brittan .
you have to have confidence in the way the home office scrutinised the team .
the caller says woolf should resign .
q : last week you said , in relation to ched evans , that footballers were role models .
are n't mps role models too ?
clegg says opinion in sheffield is divided over evans .
some people think he should be allowed to play again .
clegg says he thinks the club should bear in mind that players are role models .
q : but mps were allowed to return to their jobs after the expenses scandal .
clegg says many mps caught up in that did not return to their jobs .
on evans , he says he has not struck a single note of remorse .
q : the bbc have had to apologise after michael buerk said the victim was so drunk she could hardly stand .
clegg says he does not want to second guess the court .

text: q : what do you think of the threat to cancel a show in paris because someone in the audience was wearing a veil ?
clegg says he does not know about this story .
nick ferrari explains the story .
there 's an account of it here .
clegg says this sounds ridiculous .
q : but she was breaking the law .
clegg says he is talking about this country .
he thinks there are circumstances , like court or the classroom , where wearing a veil is not appropriate .
but generally there should not be laws telling people what they should wear , he says .
the woman paid good money to see the opera , he says .
overnight the main news has been the nhs five year forward view report .
denis campbell has written it up in the guardian splash and here 's how his story starts .

the nhs is asking for an additional £ 8bn by 2020 to implement a radical plan , including switching funding from hospitals into other services including gp surgeries , which bosses say is vital to ensure the service can safeguard its future .

nhs bosses warn the westminster parties to accept the need for the service 's funding to increase from just under £ 100bn this year to around £ 120bn by the end of the next parliament - an extra £ 8bn on top of planned increases in line with inflation - or risk patients suffering severe '' consequences .
and here 's denis 's analysis of the full report .
there will be more comment on it as the day goes on , and i 'll that up .
but i will be focusing in particular on the intelligence and security committee hearings .
for obvious reasons , its inquiry is of key interest to the guardian .
here 's the full agenda for the day .
9am : nick clegg hosts his lbc phone-in .
9.30am : theresa may , the home secretary , gives a speech to the policing and mental health summit .

as alan travis reports , she will announce an in-depth review of the use of force by police amid particular concerns that physical restraint and tasers are being used too often against mentally distressed people .
10.10am : david laws , the education minister , gives a speech to the 4children conference .
he will announce new pupil premium rates .
11.15am : sir david omand , the former head of gchq , gives evidence to the intelligence and security committee .
11.45am : ed miliband campaigns in rochester and strood .
1pm : philip hammond , the foreign secretary , gives evidence to the intelligence and security committee .
1.15pm : parick mcloughlin , the transport secretary , gives a speech to the hs2 supply chain conference .
2.40pm : jeremy hunt , the health secretary , gives a speech at the nhs best practice conference .
3pm : david cameron arrives at the eu summit in brussels .
as usual , i will be also covering all the breaking political news from westminster , as well as bringing you the most interesting political comment and analysis from the web and from twitter .
i will post a summary at lunchtime , and another at the end of the day .
if you want to follow me on twitter , i 'm on @ twitterid .
